recordings.loc: Winters Ridge, Tejon Ranch, Kern County, California
recordings.rmk:
Recorded along the top of the ridge in open oak woodland.  The dominant tree in the area is valley oak with scattered blue oak.

Equipment: Sony PCM-M10 and a Sennheiser ME67.
Edits to the file: trimmed at both ends and normalized to -3 dB.

recordings.loc: San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge, Cochise County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: rare species here in winter, 2 m up on interior perch in leafless mesquite, another bird audible faintly off to the side, a total of four birds present; I moved closer several times, some cosmetic edits to deal with that, the song being extremely quiet; in general, this growl song or chatter song something I hear from migrant or wintering birds; some very soft growl after 2:20, barely audible to me at about 7 m distance; loudest part is after 3:12, after I had moved closer three times and the bird was singing a quiet-but-louder song plus my being closer, this part the 'A' part; some wind hiss; looks like some little notes in the growl songs would need more amplification for me to hear them;

recordings.loc: Smoky Valley Ranch s. of Oakley, Logan County, Kansas
recordings.file-name: XC422086-SVR (APEC area), Logan Co., KS- LASP (singing from yucca), CASP- 0815- 24Jun18.mp3
recordings.rmk: A single adult-plumaged bird singing from atop a yucca plant. A Cassin's Sparrow was singing in that very spot minutes before but the sparrows did not show aggressive behaviors toward each other. The habitat was dominated by yucca and sand-sage with a grassy base layer. Not a flat location but fingers of gullies characterized this spot, creating many high and low spots. Bison grunts can also be heard in the latter half of the recording.

recordings.loc: Walnut Creek, Contra Costa County, California
recordings.rmk: Flock of about 40 LASPs flew up from the ground to the live oak trees. One young bird started singing this sub-song with with noticeable low-pitched trills. Due to wind this is only a small portion of a longer recording. High filer pass (1000 Hz) used.

recordings.loc: Delicias, Delicias Municipality, Chihuahua
Wisconsin (near  Spring Green), Sauk County, Wisconsin
recordings.rmk: This bird sang multiple times; I cropped my recording to one song because talking is interspersed throughout the rest of it.  The bird was seen vocalizing. There were actually three total LASP's that we observed this trip (this area is a locality for them). This one was flying around the dry sand prairie, perching (if I recall correctly) on the ground and on small shrubs that are scattered throughout the area. Great looks at the bird, too!

recordings.loc: Edinburg, Hidalgo, Texas
recordings.rmk: Natural calls from a pair from power lines. The more rapid series was while performing copulation, after which, they flew down into brush and probably copulated a couple more times.

recordings.loc: Poway, San Diego County, California
recordings.rmk: This was the first time I've ever seen Lark Sparrows at Lake Poway, and as far as I know the first officially recorded proof of their presence in this location.  There were four individuals seen at the start of my trip, mere minutes from when I stepped out of the parking lot and onto the hill surrounding the baseball field.  All four were seen together in the defoliated tree just above the tree closest to the field on the parking lot side.  They were constantly hopping sound the surrounding trees, but one individual remained in that defoliated tree for the entire duration, and it's the one on the recording.

recordings.loc: Deer Creek Hills Preserve, Sacramento County, California
recordings.rmk: Songs from one individual recorded pre-dawn; of interest is lack of any of the buzzes or churrs typical of this species (is this dawn song?) and the dramatically up-slurred notes which are used as introductory notes in some songs, and incorporated into the middle or at the end of a couple. This note is up-slurred through a full 2kHz and I can not recall hearing anything quite like it before from this species and can't find any examples in other XC recordings. No modification of this recording but I did swing the microphone around at one point to pick up calling COPO briefly before aiming back at the Lark Sparrow.

recordings.loc: Trenton, Gibson County, Tennessee
recordings.rmk: I was walking in a field that was mostly bare ground but contained a lot of Horseweed or Marestail (Conyza canadensis). I had found one Lark Sparrow nest at the base of a clump of Horseweed. As I walked through the field looking for additional nests, the nearby adult Lark Sparrows started giving the call notes which I recorded on my iPhone 6 and then uploaded to my computer and converted the file from m4a to mp3.

Location is a suburban park with ponds.

Equipment: Olympus LS-10S and a Sennheiser MKE-400 microphone.
